Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Perioperative Normoxia vs. Hyperoxia in Cyanotic Neonates Undergoing Cardiopulmonary Bypass

Trial_Design.evidence: In this randomised controlled trial, 29 neonates with cyanotic congenital heart disease were enrolled at a single tertiary care center.

Participants.evidence: 29 neonates with cyanotic congenital heart disease were enrolled at a single tertiary care center.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised to either normoxia (PaO2 60–100 mmHg) or hyperoxia (PaO2 200–300 mmHg) during cardiopulmonary bypass.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the feasibility, safety, and oxidative stress response of perioperative normoxia versus hyperoxia in cyanotic neonates undergoing cardiopulmonary bypass.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was serum thiobarbituric acid reactive substances (TBARS) measured at baseline, 2, 6, and 24 hours postoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Fifteen neonates were randomised to normoxia and 14 to hyperoxia.

Result_Outcome.evidence: TBARS levels were significantly lower in the normoxia group at all time points (p<0.01).

Harms.evidence: No severe adverse events were reported.
